A salt induced gelatin crosslinking strategy to prepare Fe-N doped aligned porous carbon for efficient oxygen reduction reaction catalysts and high-performance supercapacitors Pengfei Tian Yanhui Wang Wei Li Shiwei Song Shuyu Zhou Hongwei Gao Hanqing Xu Xueqing Tian Jianbing Zang ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao 066004, PR China State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology College of Materials Science and Engineering Yanshan University Qinhuangdao 066004 PR China State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao 066004, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The preparation of low-cost, high-efficiency and stable oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts is highly anticipated but remains a challenge. Herein, a novel strategy of CaCl2 solution inducing gelatin crosslinking and acting as aligned pore template was put forward for preparation of Fe-N doped aligned hierarchical porous carbon. Furthermore, the microtopography and length of aligned pore can be controlled by adding NaCl solution. The prepared catalyst exhibited short-range aligned honeycomb hierarchical porous structure with large specific surface area and highly homogeneous distribution of Fe-Nx active sites (Fe-NHHPC-900). Notably, in addition to excellent durability in the alkaline electrolyte, Fe-NHHPC-900 possessed excellent ORR performance with positive half-wave potential of 0.86 V, superior to commercial Pt/C catalysts. As electrode materials of supercapacitors, Fe-NHHPC-900 also displayed a high specific capacitance, excellent rate performance and excellent stability. This work also proved that the unique aligned porous structure can effectively optimize catalyst activity and improve supercapacitor performance. Keywords Fe-N doped Aligned hierarchical porous carbon Oxygen reduction reaction Supercapacitors 1 Introduction With the resource depletion on the earth and the deterioration of the living environment, developing clean energy as well as energy storage and conversion devices has widely concerned [1,2]. However, the application in practice of fuel cells and metal-air batteries is limited by the low efficient kinetic process of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts [3,4]. At present, Pt-based catalysts are considered to be the most effective catalyst for ORR. Nevertheless, its shortcomings of high cost, limited stability, fuel crossover effect, and Pt dissolution cannot be ignored [5,6]. Therefore, from a long-term perspective, developing of low-cost, high-efficiency and durable catalysts for ORR becomes crucial to promote the commercial use of metal-air batteries and fuel cells in various industries. Currently, a variety of non-precious metal catalysts have been extensively researched for ORR, such as metal-free heteroatom-doped carbon materials [7,8], carbides [9,10], nitrides [11,12], transition metal oxides [13,14], and transition metal-nitrogen-doped carbon (M−N/C) catalysts [15–18]. Among them, Fe-N/C material catalysts are regarded to be one of the most promising alternative commercial platinum-based catalysts. Because Fe-Nx coordinating active sites of Fe-N moieties and nitrogen doping on the surface of catalysts can cause an unbalanced distribution of charge in carbon structure and thus facilitate the O2 adsorption and reduction [19–22]. Recently, numerous Fe-N/C materials catalysts are developed for the synthesis of an efficient catalytic targeting ORR. It is meaningful to explore a facile approach to synthesize of a Fe-N/C material catalyst, which can not only expose more efficient active sites but also facilitate efficient mass transport. In addition to the control of the composition, the specific surface area and the structure of the carbon support material are also of importance to display the excellent catalyst properties of the active material for ORR [23]. Various carbon support structural materials have been designed and used as ORR catalysts, such as Fe-N-doped porous carbon foam [24,25], Fe-N-doped carbon nanotube aerogels [26], Fe-N-codoped carbon nanofibers [27,28], and Fe-N doped hollow carbon nanoparticles [29,30], etc. Characterized by the large specific surface area and the hierarchical porous structure with abundant micro/meso/macropores, the hierarchical porous structure becomes one of the most excellent carbon support materials. Specifically, the large specific surface area can expose more active sites of catalysts in the electrolyte; and the hierarchical porous structure contributes to the sufficient contact of the catalyst with the electrolyte and facilitates the mass transport of reactants, intermediates, and products [31–33]. Still, the disordered and disconnected pore structure is faced with certain obstacles to the rapid transfer of matter due to the uncertain transmission path. Therefore, to seek a simple method for preparing a catalyst with interconnected aligned and hierarchical porous structure support becomes essential to optimize catalyst performance. Meanwhile, the aligned and hierarchical porous structure is also beneficial to improve the electric double-layer supercapacitor′s performance [34,35]. The hierarchical porous structure with micropores/mesopores/macropores can provide energy storage sites, provide a fast channel for ion transport, and serve as ion buffering reservoirs, respectively [36–40]. The unique structure also allows the sufficient contact of the electrode material with the electrolyte, thereby fully utilizing the specific surface area of the porous carbon. The aligned porous structure also facilitate ion transport due to unobstructed transmission channels. In this way, the electrode material maintains an outstanding specific capacitance and excellent rate performance even at high current density. Herein, a novel strategy of initiating gelatin crosslinking using CaCl2 solution was proposed to prepare the Fe-Nx doped aligned porous carbon active material. Besides as the carbon source and nitrogen source, gelatin was also a polypeptide compound with abundant surface functional groups making Fe3+ ions evenly dispersed in the carbon precursor. As displayed in Fig. 1 a, furthermore, certain concentrations of CaCl2 were added to the iron-containing gelatin solution causing gelatin crosslinking to form the gel due to Ca2+ ions binding with carboxyl groups in gelatin. Meanwhile, Ca2+ ions also acted as templates for the construction of the aligned hierarchical porous structure during the carbonization process. Furthermore, the addition of Na+ ions also played the role of adjusting the length of the aligned pore. Therefore, the Fe-N doped long-range aligned and hierarchical porous carbon (Fe-NAHPC-900) and Fe-N doped short-range aligned honeycomb hierarchical porous carbon (Fe-NHHPC-900) were obtained after heating treatment at 900 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere. The as-prepared porous carbon active materials exhibited a large specific surface area with a homogeneous distribution of Fe and N doped. Notably, Fe-NHHPC-900 exhibited superior catalytic activity and remarkable catalytic stability for ORR performance in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte, indicating promising alternative commercial Pt-based catalysts. In addition, as supercapacitor electrode materials, Fe-NHHPC-900 also exhibited excellent specific capacitance and excellent rate performance. The test results also proved that the unique porous structure can effectively optimize catalyst activity and improve supercapacitor performance. As a practical application, a flexible solid PVA/KOH supercapacitor showed a better performance as well. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Gelatin was a food grade purchased from Taobao (China). Ferric chloride, sodium chloride and calcium chloride were of analytical grade. The concentration of hydrochloric acid was 36 wt%. Deionized water (resistance >18 MΩ cm−1) was used in the experimental process. 2.2 Preparation of gelatin gel The preparation process is shown in Fig. 1a and detailed as bellow. First, 3 g gelatin was dissolved in 50 ml of deionized water and stirred magnetically to form a clear solution. Then 6 m mol FeCl3 was added to the gelatin solution to form a uniform brown-red solution under continuous magnetic stirring. Subsequently, 50 ml 4.8 M NaCl and 1.8 M CaCl2 were added dropwise into the above solution under constant magnetic stirring producing a brown-red gelatinous substance. Then the brown-red gelatinous substance was freeze-dried at −80 °C for 24 h and marked as Fe-Gel-Na/Ca. With the same preparation process as above, the prepared gel by adding 50 ml 1.8 M CaCl2 solution and 50 ml 4.8 M NaCl solution was marked as Fe-Gel-Ca and Fe-Gel-Na, respectively. The gelatin without a salt solution was named as Fe-Gel and the gelatin containing no FeCl3 was recorded as Gel-Na/Ca. 2.3 Synthesis of Fe-N doped microporous porous carbon The as-prepared Fe-Gel-Na was heated at 900 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere for 1 h. Subsequently, the heat-treated sample was first washed with deionized water to remove the salt, then soaked in 2 M HCl at 60 °C for 24 h and washed with deionized water until neutral. Finally, the obtained sample dried at 70 °C in a vacuum oven was marked as Fe-NPC-900. 2.4 Synthesis of Fe-N doped long-range aligned hierarchical porous carbon The as-prepared Fe-Gel-Ca was heated at 900 °C in a nitrogen atmosphere for 1 h. Subsequently, the obtained sample using the same subsequent process as above was named as Fe-NAHPC-900. 2.5 Synthesis of Fe-N doped short-range oriented honeycomb hierarchical porous carbon The as-prepared Fe-Gel-Na/Ca was heated at 900 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere for 1 h. Subsequently, the obtained sample using the same subsequent process as above was named as Fe-NHHPC-900. Meanwhile, Fe-Gel-Na/Ca heat-treated at 700 °C and 800 °C were named as Fe-NHHPC-700 and Fe-NHHPC-800, respectively. In addition, Fe-NC-900 and NPC-900 were prepared by heating Fe-Gel and Gel-Na/Ca at 900 °C in a nitrogen atmosphere for 1 h. 2.6 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was detected at a D/MAX-2500 PC (Japan) with Cu Kα radiation. Raman spectra were determined by a Renishaw in Via Raman microscope with a 532 nm laser. The microscopic morphology and structure of as-prepared materials were inspected by the scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S4800II) and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM, Talos F200X). Nitrogen sorption isotherms were operated at 77 K using an ASAP2020 analyzer to survey the specific surface area and pore structure characteristics. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250XI) was used to detect the elemental composition, content, and configurations of prepared materials. 2.7 ORR performance measurement A CHI760E (CH Instrument, China) electrochemical workstation was used to carry out electrochemical measurements under a three-electrode system. A Graphite rod and Hg/HgO (1 M KOH) were selected as counter electrode and reference electrode. For the working electrodes, 5 mg prepared sample was dispersed in 1 ml N, N-dimethylformamide containing 100 μl Nafion (5 wt%) to form an average ink. Then 10 μl of the above ink was dripped onto a rotating disk electrode (RDE, 0.19 cm2) and dried under room temperature. The CV measurement was carried out in 0.1 M KOH with N2 and O2 saturated at 50 mV s−1, and Linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) was tested in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH from 400 to 2500 rpm at 10 mV s−1. The value of reaction electron number (n) of ORR was obtained from the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots from 400 to 2500 rpm [23]. The kinetic current density can be calculated from the mass-transport correction of RDE by: (1) J k = J d × J / J d - J where J, Jk, and Jd are the measured current density, kinetic current density, and diffusion-limiting current density, respectively [41,42]. The potential at the intersection of the tangents just before and after the onset of rise in the current density in the LSV curve was defined as the onset potential (Eonset) [43]. The rotary ring disk electrode (RRDE) test was implemented in an N2 and O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at 1600 rpm with 10 mV s−1. The value of n and the production of H2O2 in the catalytic oxygen reduction process were calculated by the Eq. (2) and (3): (2) n = 4 I D / ( I D + I R / N ) (3) H 2 O 2 % = 2 I R / N / ( I D + I R / N ) × % where N means the H2O2 collection efficiency of the Pt ring (N = 0.37), I R , and I D are the responsive ring and disk current, respectively. 2.8 Scs performance measurement SCs performance test as follows: Under the three-electrode system, galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) were conducted on the voltage from −1 to 0 V under 6 M KOH with a platinum foil as the counter electrode and a Hg/HgO (1 M KOH) as the reference electrode. For the working electrode, the active material mixed with polytetrafluoroethylene (1 wt%) at a mass ratio of 8.5/1.5 to form a slurry which was coated on a clean nickel foam (10 × 10 mm2), and then the nickel foam was pressed into flakes and dried at 70 °C at a vacuum oven. The load of the active material on each nickel foam was around 1.5 mg cm−2. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement was recorded on the frequency from 10-2 to 105 Hz at 5 mV amplitude [38]. The preparation of solid electrolyte of KOH (PVA/KOH) as follows: 4.5 g KOH was dissolved into 60 ml deionized water and then polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) power (6 g) was added under stirring at 80 °C to a clear solution. After room temperature, the gel was added dropwise onto two the nickel foam active material electrodes. Then the two electrodes and NKK-MPF30AC-100 as the diaphragm and polyethylene film as the package were assembled into a flexible supercapacitor. The specific capacitances of active materials (C, F g−1) with three electrode system based on GCD were obtained as follows: (4) C = I Δ t / m Δ V where I , Δ t , m , and Δ V mean the applied current (A), discharge time (s), the mass of an electrode active material (g) and the discharge slope after IR drop (V). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microstructure characterization Gelatin is a polypeptide compound and contains abundant amino functional groups, carboxylic acid functional groups, and hydroxyl functional groups [44]. Therefore it has many unique properties. In addition to being the carbon source and nitrogen source, gelatin can also effectively prevent aggregation of Fe3+ ions because of the surface functional groups strongly binding with Fe3+ ions via coordination interactions. This facilitated the uniform distribution of Fe3+ ions in the carbon precursor [20]. Meanwhile, when certain concentrations of CaCl2 or NaCl solution were added to the iron-containing gelatin solution, both Ca2+ ions and Na+ ions could bond with carboxylic acid groups on the gelatin causing the gelatin to crosslink with each other to form the gel [45,46]. The schematics of the interaction between Ca2+ ions and Na+ ions and gelatin molecules are shown in Fig. 1b, c and d. The aligned and hierarchical porous structure was constructed during the process of carbonization based on Ca2+ ions or Na+ ions as templates, and Na+ ions also played a role in adjusting the length of the aligned pore. SEM was used to observe the microscopic morphology of the prepared active materials. In Fig. S1, the Fe-NPC-900 prepared in NaCl solution showed a block structure with orderless macropores which were formed by the removal of NaCl after washing. Obviously, the SEM image of Fe-NAHPC-900 (Fig. 2 a and b) displayed a directionally aligned and uniformly long-range porous carbon structure. This phenomenon was attributed to that carboxylic acid functional groups of the gelatin were linked to each other by Ca2+ ions which also acted as a template of directionally aligned pores during high-temperature carbonization. However, as displayed in Fig. 2c, the Fe-NHHPC-900 prepared in NaCl and CaCl2 mixed solution exhibited a 3 D hierarchical honeycomb porous carbon structure. In addition, the side of the fracture of Fe-NHHPC-900 (Fig. 2d) also displayed a short-range oriented and interconnected pore structure. This is because Na+ ions bonded with carboxylic acid groups of the gelatin as well, thus blocking long-range and orderly linkage of Ca2+ ions to carboxylic acid groups. And due to the role of Na+ ions in tailoring during high-temperature carbonization, Fe-NHHPC-900 formed a short-range oriented honeycomb porous carbon structure. Therefore, the microstructure of the formed porous carbon for the prepared samples was adjusted the microstructure of the formed porous carbon by the composition of the salt solution. Such unique aligned and long-range porous structure and short-range oriented 3 D hierarchical honeycomb porous structure can facilitate efficient mass transport and the exposure of active sites during the electrocatalytic process. The microstructures of Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NHHPC-900 were further studied by STEM. As displayed in Fig. 3 a and b, the Fe-NAHPC-900 showed directionally aligned and uniformly arranged mesoporous with a certain length running through the carbon structure. This mesoporous structure can provide a fast transmission path for mass transport, which is beneficial to the enhancement of catalyst performance. It can be seen from Fig. 3c that there were no metal particles embedded in carbon nanostructure. The selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED, inset of Fig. 3c) displayed ring-like, confirming low crystallinity of carbon and absence of metal particles. This result indicated that Fe-NAHPC-900 was a porous carbon structure. In Fig. 3d, the elemental mapping images of Fe-NAHPC-900 demonstrated that N and Fe indeed existed and were highly homogeneously distributed in the carbon structure. Meanwhile, TEM images of Fe-NHHPC-900 (Fig. 3e and f) displayed a 3D interconnected honeycomb porous structure, and these pores are distributed in the mesoporous range. In Fig. 3g, the HRTEM of Fe-NHHPC-900 displayed the worm-like amorphous carbon characteristic with a porous structure, and no metal particles embedded in carbon nanostructure were detected. The ring-like SAED pattern (inset of Fig. 3g) further confirmed the low crystallinity of carbon and absence of particles existence, which was consistent with the results of the HRTEM image. Moreover, the elemental mapping images of Fe-NHHPC-900 are displayed in Fig. 3h. Obviously, N element was uniformly doped in the carbon structure and Fe element was also highly homogeneously distributed in Fe-NHHPC-900. Therefore, highly homogeneous distribution of Fe was speculated in carbon structures of Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NHHPC-900 carbon structure in quite small clusters such as Fe-Nx coordination, rather than in form of Fe-based nanoparticles. The crystal structures of Fe-NPC-900, Fe-NAHPC-900, and Fe-NHHPC-900 were analyzed by XRD measurement. As shown in Fig. 4 a, all samples only showed two characteristic peaks at 24.9° and 43.2° corresponding to the (0 0 2) and (1 0 0) diffractions of amorphous carbon, respectively [21]. No other diffraction peaks can be detected, indicating the absence of Fe-based nanoparticles in Fe-NPC-900, Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NHHPC-900. These results were consistent with HRTEM images. Subsequently, Raman spectra (Fig. 4b) of samples exhibited typical D (1350 cm−1) and G (1590 cm−1) bands of carbon material characteristics[47]. Fe-NHHPC-900 had the largest intensity ratio of D/G peak of 0.89 compared with Fe-NPC-900 (0.82) and Fe-NAHPC-900 (0.87). It indicates more defects in Fe-NHPC-900 structure, which may be attributed to edge defects caused by pores in the carbon structure and the doping of heteroatoms [48]. Furthermore, N2 adsorption and desorption measurement was used to analyze the pore structure and specific surface areas of Fe-NHHPC-900, Fe-NAHPC-900, and Fe-NPC-900. As seen in Fig. 4c, the strongly rapid N2 adsorption in the low pressure indicated that micropore structure existed in Fe-NHHPC-900, Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NPC-900. In addition, the curves of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 showed a typical type of IV isotherms with an obvious hysteresis loop at 0.5 < p/p0 < 1.0 compared with the curve of Fe-NPC-900. This indicated that there were abundant mesopores in Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 [38]. The detailed pore size distribution curves are displayed in Fig. 4d. It can be seen that all three samples possessed microporous. Moreover, Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 also had abundant mesopores and macropores. And Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 exhibited a similar size of mesopore which was concentrated in the range of 10–30 nm and around 40 nm. Combined with SEM and TEM images, it demonstrated that the size of directionally aligned pores in Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 were mostly distributed in the mesopore range. The detailed pore structure information of the three samples is shown in Table 1 . Fe-NHHPC-900 had the highest specific surface area of 943.0 m2 g−1 compared with Fe-NPC-900 of 762.4 m2 g−1 and Fe-NAHPC-900 of 767.4 m2 g−1. Both Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NHHPC-900 showed higher mesopore volume than Fe-NPC-900. And Fe-NAHPC-900 had the highest micropore volume. This benefited from the formation of directionally aligned and uniformly arranged mesoporous structure and the 3D interconnected honeycomb mesoporous structure which were considered to be favorable carbon support nanostructures for catalysts and supercapacitors. To gain more insights, the content and composition of elements and the valence configuration on the surface of the prepared samples were investigated by XPS. In Fig. 5 a, the peaks of C (284.6 eV), N (401.0 eV), and O (532.0 eV) in the survey spectrum can be obviously observed [26]. There is no notable peak of Fe in the survey spectrum, which was attributed to the relatively low content of Fe. The detailed element content is listed in Table S1. Fe-NHHPC-900 had the highest N content (3.2 at%) and Fe content (0.6 at%) compared with Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NPC-900. Moreover, the N content of Fe-NHHPC-900, Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NPC-900 were higher than that of NPC-900. This may be attributed to the addition of Fe, promoting the formation of nitrogen bound to the metal (Fe-Nx). To further research the configuration of N in the catalyst, the high-resolution N 1 s spectra of the samples and NPC-900 are displayed in Fig. 5b and Fig. S2. The peaks located at 402.9, 401.5, 400.0, 399.0 and 398.5 eV can be fitted and corresponded to oxide-N, graphitic-N, pyrrole-N, Fe-N, and pyridinic-N, respectively [49]. The contents of different N configurations of samples in percentages were contrasted in Fig. 5c. It can be clearly seen that all samples had similar proportions of different N configurations. Notably, Fe-NHHPC-900 had the highest content of pyridinic-N, graphitic-N and Fe-N. Research has proven that pyridinic-N and graphitic-N are beneficial to improve the ORR activity of carbon materials, and pyridinic-N and pyrrole-N can bond with Fe atoms to form effective Fe-Nx catalytic active sites for ORR [23]. The low surface concentration of Fe-centers and relatively high noise level, this made the peak of high-resolution spectra of Fe 2p not obvious (Fig. 5d). Due to the low Fe content and no segregated phase of Fe metal particles in TEM and XRD results, it can be inferred that Fe was uniformly distributed in the carbon structure in small clusters of Fe-Nx configurations. 3.2 ORR catalytic activity Due to the doping of Fe and N with uniform distribution and the unique porous nanostructure, the prepared samples are expected to have excellent catalytic ORR performance. The catalytic activity of as-prepared samples was first evaluated by CV and LSV measurement on an RDE in a three-electrode system. In Fig. 6 a, CV curves of the samples were recorded in N2 and O2 saturation 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at 50 mV s−1. Both Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 displayed an obvious and more positive cathode reduction peak (0.80 V) on the O2-saturated CV curves compared to other samples. It indicated that Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 exhibited positive catalytic activity for ORR. In Fig. 6b, the LSV curves of the prepared samples were compared in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH at 1600 rpm with 10 mV s−1. Fe-NHHPC-900 showed the most positive ORR catalytic activity with the onset potential (Eonset, 0.94 V) and half-wave potential (E1/2, 0.86 V) and Fe-NAHPC-900 also displayed better ORR catalytic activity (Eonset, 0.93 V and E1/2, 0.85 V). Their catalytic performance were superior to that of Fe-NC-900 (0.92 and 0.72 V), Fe-NPC-900 (0.92 and 0.82 V), and NPC-900 (0.83 and 0.70 V). Meanwhile, Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 also exhibited better catalytic performance than that of Pt/C (20 wt%, 0.92 and 0.81 V) in Fig. 6c, indicating excellent ORR catalytic activity. The above comparison results indicated that the formed Fe-Nx active sites significantly enhanced catalytic activity of the catalyst contrasted with NPC-900. Although Fe-NPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 had similar N and Fe-N contents, Fe-NAHPC-900 displayed more excellent catalytic properties, which is attributed to the hierarchical and aligned porous structure of Fe-NAHPC-900 to optimize its catalytic performance. And short-range aligned honeycomb hierarchical porous structure of Fe-NHHPC-900 possessed the highest specific surface area and highest Fe-N content, which ensured the exposure of the active sites to exhibit the best catalytic performance. In addition, the effect of the heat treatment temperature on the performance of the catalyst was also studied. In Fig. S3a, Fe-NHPC-900 catalyst possessed the most positive Eonset and E1/2 and the largest limiting current density compared to Fe-NHPC-800 and Fe-NHPC-700, indicating a vital influence of the heat-treatment temperature on the ORR activity. In addition, the Tafel slopes of the prepared samples and Pt/C (20 wt%) are displayed in Fig. 6d. The Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 exhibited small Tafel slopes of 61.0 and 66.1 mV dec-1 which were close to that of Pt/C (69.2 mV dec-1). This indicated that the first electron transfer was probably the rate-determining step for Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 catalysts, which were similar to reaction mechanism of the Pt/C catalyst [51,52]. Meanwhile, the kinetic current density (Jk) at 0.81 V vs.RHE of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 displayed high Jk of 33.5 and 22.7 mA cm2, respectively (Fig. S3b). Both of them were significantly superior to that of Fe-NC-900 (2.9 mA cm2), Fe-NPC-900 (5.3 mA cm2) and Pt/C (9.5 mA cm2). This result further demonstrated that the prepared catalyst with the hierarchical and aligned porous structure was favorable to the kinetic process of ORR. In order to understand the pathway and kinetics of ORR, the LSV curves of Fe-NHHPC-900 and other samples in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at different rotation rates are displayed in Figs. 6e and S4. In Fig. 6e, a small peak can be observed in LSV curves at low rotation rate and was disappeared as the rotation rate increases, indicating that the measured LSV curves might be affected by minor non-steady state effects [53–55]. The limiting current density increased gradually with the rotation rate increasing owing to the shorter diffusion distance. In the inset of Fig. 6e, the K-L plots of Fe-NHHPC-900 from 0.4 to 0.7 V were investigated and displayed excellent linearity suggesting first-order reaction kinetics with respect to O2 concentration [23]. The comparison of the value of n is shown in Fig. 6f. Both Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 were the closest to four value of n, proving a high efficient catalytic process with a near four-electron reaction. The excellent catalytic performance can be attributed to the following two aspects: (1) The formationof Fe-Nx configurations in the carbon structure provided efficient active sites for ORR; (2) The unique aligned and long-range porous structure and the short-range oriented 3 D hierarchical honeycomb porous carbon expose more active sites and facilitate the efficient mass transport of reactants, intermediates, and products. To further investigative the pathway and kinetics process of the catalytic ORR of Fe-NPC-900, Fe-NAHPC-900, and Fe-NHHPC-900, RRDE curves were carried out in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at 1600 rpm with 10 mV s−1 and are recorded in Fig. 7 a. During the process of catalytic ORR, the H2O2 generated on the disk electrode was accurately calculated by the ring electrode, and the values of n and the yield of H2O2 are shown in Fig. 7b. Obviously, Fe-NHHPC-900 had the least yield of H2O2 (less of 3.5%) and the highest value of n which was consistent with the results calculated by the K-L equation. Meanwhile, Fe-NAHPC-900 also displayed a low yield of H2O2 (less of 6.8%) and a high value of n which were very close to the values of Fe-NHHPC-900. This indicated high efficient ORR catalytic activity and a near-ideal four-electron reaction kinetics process of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 catalysts. In addition, by the comparison with the previous Fe-N porous carbon-based catalysts regarding ORR performance in Table S2, both the prepared Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 catalysts displayed excellent catalytic performance. The previous studies have demonstrated that SCN- has a strong affinity to iron and can poison Fe-Nx active sites that catalyze ORR [15,50]. Therefore, the ORR catalyst of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 were carried out at O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 and 0.1 M HClO4 with 0.01 M KSCN at 1600 rpm. As shown in Figs. 7c and S5, the half-wave potential obviously negatively shifted after adding 0.01 M KSCN into 0.1 M HClO4. This phenomenon can be attributed to the strong affinity of SCN- for Fe ions covering Fe-Nx active sites and hence deactivating the catalyst. This also indicated the existence of Fe-Nx active sites for catalyzing ORR in Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900. Durability was a crucial parameter for catalysts. The durability of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 were measured at 0.7 V (vs. RHE) in O2 -saturated 0.1 M KOH at 1600 rpm by a Current versus time (i–t) chronoamperometric method. As displayed in Fig. 7d, after 12000 s testing, Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 still maintained 93.6% and 92.1% of initial current density, respectively, better than Pt/C of 81.5%, indicating excellent stability as highly efficient ORR catalysts. 3.3 Scs performance As the as-prepared material exhibited a unique porous structure with abundant micropores and mesopores, the electrochemical properties of the as-prepared electrode materials of supercapacitors were evaluated in 6 M KOH. The comparison of CV curves of Fe-NPC-900, Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 at a high scan rate of 500 mV s−1 are shown in Fig. 8 a. The CV curves of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 exhibited an approximately rectangular shape indicating the characteristics of an ideal electric-double layer capacitor and excellent rate performance. The CV curves of the samples from 2 to 500 mV s−1 are displayed in Fig. S6. All samples showed no obvious redox peaks at different scan rates, suggesting that the contribution of the specific capacitance was mainly derived from the electric double-layer capacitor [38]. The GCD curve of the samples at 1 A g−1 are compared in Fig. 8b. The GCD curve of Fe-NHHPC-900 showed a symmetrical isosceles triangle shape, proving excellent reversibility; its longest discharge time indicates the highest specific capacitance compared with Fe-NPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900. The GCD curve of the samples from 0.5 to 20 A g−1 are displayed in Fig. S7. The GCD curves of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 also exhibited good symmetry of isosceles triangle and there were no obvious voltage drop even at a high current density of 20 A g−1, indicating excellent reversibility and a small internal resistance [40]. As displayed in Fig. 8c, Fe-NHHPC-900 had the highest specific capacitance at 0.5 A g−1 (328.6 F g−1) compared with Fe-NAHPC-900 (252.5 F g−1) and Fe-NPC-900 (180.6 F g−1). Meanwhile, the capacitance retention of Fe-NHPC-900 (76.9%) was also superior to that of Fe-NAHPC-900 (69.7%) and Fe-NPC-900 (47.2%) at a high current density of 20 A g−1. The Nyquist plots of prepared samples are shown in Fig. S8 and were discussed in the support material. Fe-NHHPC-900 displayed the highest specific capacitance which attributed to the high specific surface area with hierarchical porous structure. Meanwhile, Fe-NHHPC-900 also had better capacitance retention than Fe-NAHPC-900, it maybe speculates that short-range aligned and interconnected hierarchical porous structure was more conducive to the rapid mass transfer compared with the long-range aligned porous structure. Although Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NPC-900 have close specific surface areas, Fe-NAHPC-900 exhibited higher specific capacitance and better rate performance than Fe-NPC-900. Those results proved that the long-range aligned and hierarchical porous structure of Fe-NAHPC-900 enable the electrode material to be insufficient contact with the electrolyte, thus fully utilizing the specific surface area and providing a fast channel for ion transport. To investigate the durability of the electrode material, the stability test of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NHAPC-900 was carried out by GCD measurement at a high current density of 8 A g−1 for 4,500 cycles. In Figs. 8d and S9, the GCD curve still exhibited good symmetry of isosceles triangles and there was no obvious voltage drop after 4500 cycles at high current density of 8 A g−1, indicating excellent reversibility. The specific capacitance of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NAHPC-900 only decayed by 3.9% and 4.8%, respectively, indicating excellent stability as an electrode material of SCs. Meanwhile, the specific capacitance of Fe-NHHPC-900 and Fe-NHHPC-900 was mainly derived from the ion-adsorption and desorption of the surface of the active material. The result of the stability test confirmed that the unique aligned and hierarchical porous structure had high structural stability. It further illustrated that the prepared materials with a unique aligned and hierarchical porous structure are suitable for catalyst supports. In order to meet the practical application of modern energy storage, a flexible PVA/KOH supercapacitor of Fe-NHHPC-900 electrode material was fabricated through the vacuum-sealed packaging technology. The PVA/KOH supercapacitor tested by CV measurement at different degrees of bending is shown in Fig. 8e. The CV curve still maintains a good rectangular shape without significant deformation after bending 90° and 180°, indicating excellent flexibility and stability as a flexible energy storage device. In Fig. 8f, two PVA/KOH supercapacitors were connected in series and the GCD test was performed under the voltage window 0–2 V. The GCD curve exhibited good symmetry indicating excellent reversibility. And there was no obvious voltage drop indicating small resistance of the device. The two PVA/KOH supercapacitors connected in series can successfully lit 1.8 V LED lamp (inset of Fig. 8f). The above evaluation confirmed that the prepared electrode material had a potential application in flexible energy storage devices. 4 Conclusion In this work, the Fe-Nx doped porous carbon active materials were prepared by a novel strategy of CaCl2 solution initiating gelatin crosslinking. The bound of Ca2+ with the gelatin also acted as templates for the construction of the aligned hierarchical porous structure during the carbonization process. NaCl also played a role in adjusting the length of the aligned pore. The prepared active carbon materials exhibited a long-range aligned hierarchical porous structure and a short-range oriented honeycomb hierarchical porous structure by pyrolysis of the gels initiated using CaCl2 solution and mixed solution of CaCl2 and NaCl, respectively. The microtopography and pore structure of the prepared samples were controlled by adding different metal cations to initiate gelation crosslinking. Both Fe-NAHPC-900 and Fe-NHHPC-900 exhibited a large specific surface area with a highly homogeneous distribution of Fe-Nx active sites in the carbon structure. More importantly, Fe-NHHPC-900 exhibited superior catalytic activity and remarkable catalytic stability for ORR performance in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte, indicating promising alternative commercial Pt-based catalysts. In addition, as a supercapacitor electrode material, Fe-NHHPC-900 also exhibited excellent specific capacitance and excellent rate performance. As a practical application, a flexible solid PVA/KOH supercapacitor showed a better performance as well. The results also proved that the unique aligned porous structure can effectively optimize catalyst activity and improve supercapacitor performance. coredata.dc:description: The preparation of low-cost, high-efficiency and stable oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts is highly anticipated but remains a challenge. Herein, a novel strategy of CaCl2 solution inducing gelatin crosslinking and acting as aligned pore template was put forward for preparation of Fe-N doped aligned hierarchical porous carbon. Furthermore, the microtopography and length of aligned pore can be controlled by adding NaCl solution. The prepared catalyst exhibited short-range aligned honeycomb hierarchical porous structure with large specific surface area and highly homogeneous distribution of Fe-Nx active sites (Fe-NHHPC-900). Notably, in addition to excellent durability in the alkaline electrolyte, Fe-NHHPC-900 possessed excellent ORR performance with positive half-wave potential of 0.86 V, superior to commercial Pt/C catalysts. As electrode materials of supercapacitors, Fe-NHHPC-900 also displayed a high specific capacitance, excellent rate performance and excellent stability. This work also proved that the unique aligned porous structure can effectively optimize catalyst activity and improve supercapacitor performance.
coredata.dc:title: A salt induced gelatin crosslinking strategy to prepare Fe-N doped aligned porous carbon for efficient oxygen reduction reaction catalysts and high-performance supercapacitors
